												Well, I will start with the good things first. This game is fun, its very easy to pick up and its interface is fairly user friendly. Its tutorial could be a bit more in depth, but all in all if your looking to enjoy a game for a few hours and it is free this is a good way to go. I say a few hours and I dont recommend this game because thats all it takes to get from tier 1 to 4 in the ships... then at tier 4 is where the problems begin and i mean serious problems. Like world of tanks this game uses a tier system for ships with relatively weak ships at low tier and strong ships at high tier, At tier 4 you will start to see tier 9 to 11 ships, this basically ends the game. These ships have double your hp, do double your damage and have double your view range. Prepare to be destroyed over and over again.As this game has a small community 95% of games will be like this, every so often you get a rare gem of same tier ships in a game and for me this simple but engaging game is great at times like that. But having to work your way thru game after game of no contest destruction by ships much higher level is tedious at best. This then brings me onto the second problem with this game, and for me the more important issue. The people in the tier 9 to 11 ships, the games veterans. There is two sides to this and I can see both, there appears to be very few people reach these high tiers so without being placed in games against low tiers they would never be able to play these top tier monsters. But this has the knock on affect of no one will reach high tier because of what i said above.The other side is the attitude of these veterans, they are toxic and rude people. If you dare to point out the inbalance of this matchmaking their attitude is disgusting, and so I am sad to say that for once a game is ruined by the people who play it. They are rude, offer no assistance and generally a nasty group of people. 												I have played both Navyfield 1 (started mid 2009) and Navyfield 2 since launch. I have 3 level 50+ captains in NF2 so ignore what steam says about me not playing for very long. I'll try to be as in-depth but at the same time I'll give you the straight truth on what's going on with this game...Box art description: Navy Field is a game about WW2 naval battles where you choose a nation, decide which ship line to go down, then play out sea warfare in glorius 2006-era graphics. Where the game lacks in graphics, it makes up for in strategic combat that can actually be quite thrilling if you're into this sort of game. THE GRIND:Now let me get this out of the way first: This will be the make or break the game for most of you out there. There is a term for what this game puts you through and that term is "Grind". This game will require days of your life in order for you to play ANY ship beyond Tier VII. There are 11 tiers. The good news is that the first 6 tiers are fairly easy to get to by playing normally without any sort of booster or Premium(More on this later). The better news is you can get to every single ship class by Tier IV so you can try all different playstyles before you uninstall this game because of the crazy grind to Tier X.THE P2W:All in all, this game is only truly about 20%15% Pay to Win. There are no "Premium Ships" in NF2 (unlike NF1), and there are no Premium Weapons or Premium Planes or anything. Every ship/item in the game must be earned with XP from battles.The P2W currency in this game is "Gold". With Gold you can buy  "Premium", which is like a subscription and does a few 'subscriber'-like things. The main reason anyone would buy premium would be for the Credit and XP boost that comes along with it, a whopping 50% boost. ... Not the most P2W I've ever seen by far but maybe that's why it's so cheap.I've paid for Premium before, and battles where I'd average 800 xp I'd be getting about 1200 xp so there's a decent boost from it.  But the main advantage of Premium is that it unlocks extra officer slots you wouldn't normally have. This is a huge advantage and if you want to take advantage of this you could pay for a single day of Premium and this permanently unlocks the slots. EDIT: After further review, it appears as though these slots are unlocked by default. Which means I would change the amount of P2W this game is down to about 15% from 20%. But either way, that's the most pay to win aspect of this game. There are a few other things, such as items for your ship you can buy that will give you a 15% boost to your engine recharge speed or for 1000 gold (roughly $10) you can straight up buy 100,000 credits from the store. But the truth is without the EXP you gain from battles, you can't even unlock anything worth buying. So the grind they've implemented actually cuts their P2W factor down by quite a lot. Whether this is a good thing or not is up to you. ATTENTION: If you've gotten to this point and are still on board, congratulations! You might not hate this game after all! I mean, I do. But I still play it. It's a love-hate relationship. Anyway, I'll actually outline some game details so you can know what to expect.First, each nation has it's own advantages and disadvantages. For example, Japanese torpedos do WAY more damage than UK torpedos. But UK's armor on their ships can take IJN cannons all day. The different ship lines are: DD (Destroyer), CL (Light Cruiser), CA (Heavy Cruiser), BB (Battleship), CV (Aircraft Carrier), and SS (Submarine). They're each good at different things, and to win you must play on your strengths as a team of different ships. When you first choose your capatin, you'll enter into the harbor to inspect your ship and enlist crewmen. There are 4 types of crewmen: Weapons Officers, Support Officers, Engineering Officers and Aviation Officers. Each one has 3 different stats you can put points into as they level up along with your captain, who has his/her own 5 stats you can level up. All of these stats change the way your crew works. For example, if you have Weapons Officers that are high in Reload but low in Accuracy, then you'll pump out the shells but they'll spray everywhere at longer distances.Finding a battle is easy enough: Click the "Battle" button. They have a "Platoon" system in place that will allow you and 2 friends to enter in the same battle. If you have a larger group however just have everyone hit "Battle" and you'll find each other :)During battle, the goal is to be the best (insert ship class) you can be by racking up damage points and capturing objectives. If you are sunk during a battle, you can wait until the end of the battle to receive a larger EXP and Credit bonus towards your ship and crew. I would recommend this game to anybody looking for something different and interesting to play. I mean,♥♥♥♥♥♥.. it's free. What's the worst that could happen? You actually like it? HINTS:Ask questions. People will answer.Give your torps at least 1 second to arm.VISION IS OPIf you're a DD and there's a sub around, use your damn sonar. 'Gradual' firing mode is good for learning how the shooting mechanics work.AP ammo removes the armor so HE does full damage. Think ahead: Put points into your commander as if you were playing the ship you want to play from Day 1. You'll be way better off. Ex: If you're building an aircraft carrier, give your commander aviation points instead of weapons. Thanks for reading, and I apologize for any misspellings. If you need a friend to roll with, send me a request and I'll support you as best I can. I have one of each ship class and would be happy to help you in any way I could if you need it :) Just send me a pm or comment and I'll do my best!

												First, I am not going to compare this game to what will (or might be) WoWS, or the WT version of naval battles, as those are different games with a different aproach. I will try to give an objective review of the game and not its competition.Second, I won't review balance, or what I think are temporary issues. The developer is fairly reactive and each weekly patch brings a lot to the game in my opinion. There are still issues, but I judge a game by its fun and its potential.Pros:- Gameplay is fun. Very fun. It is fast paced, team-based, strategic, and skill and positioning are a huge part of the game. You'll never get bored during a game. Guaranteed. Too much to do and think about.- Gameplay is varied. Playing a BB (Battleship), a DD (Destroyer), a CV (Aircraft Carrier) or a SS (Submarine) is very different, so that you can add variety to your gameplay from one game to the other or just find your playstyle. Each ship has its role (even 2 CLs can have very different roles depending on their loadout). You constantly switch between weapons (guns, torps, planes, mines, depth charges, AA, ...) and try to make the most out of it while navigating your ship. Significantly different maps. Game is surprisingly deep.- Beginning progression is very fast so you can get any class of ship within hours, and then you have to invest your time to get the top tiers. They just boosted permanently XP and credit gain by 2 and 1.5 respectively, for everyone.- Game makes it in a way that a tier I can take out a tier VII if played correctly/smartly. Very rewarding.- NOT Pay 2 Win. Premium account gives you the usual XP and Credit boost for faster progression. Some real money items give increased (temporary) stats in game but to the order of 10% max; which is definitely overcome by skill and teamplay. It is more P2W than games with a pure cosmetic cash shop, but I strongly believe the advantages are not significant.- Developer is its own publisher/editor, on this instance of the game, which means faster development cycle and patches.- Easy game to get into (simple basic controls, basic goals, immediate action, ...) ...Cons:- ... but difficult to actually understand. Poor documentation and tutorials forces you to discover things by yourself, or ask the community, to understand better how to play. Community is decent and people will answer your questions. This problem sometimes leads to frustration, but it is rewarding to get to know the game better. Lots of "Eureka" moments.- Linked to the above, but the game has its quirks, ie some unintuitive stuff from controls to interface. You get used to it after a few hours.- "Korean grind" game. 												I've played this game a few months and have about 900 games under my belt.  If you're looking for a free-to-play naval game with arcade like gameplay then you should give this game a shot.  I only recommend it as such though, do not expect 100% realistic gameplay or you will be dissapointed.Pros:1)  Ship types are not only useful but neccessary for a team to win.  A team with 10 Battle Ships will lose to a mixed force that plays the map properly.2)  Similar to World of Tanks there are smaller vessels that exist in high tiers.  Think of it as light tanks or medium tanks at high tiers except with ships.  They all have their role on the battlefield.4)  Personal skill means a lot.  You cannot simply stomp someone just because you have a higher tier ship.  If you rush in without care then you will see lower tier ships mop the floor with you.5)  Rock-Paper-Scissors balance.  As stated above you need a mixed force however you can get hard countered by certain ships.  Submarines are able to take out Battle Ships and Aircraft Carriers with ease if the Destroyers and Light Cruisers do not hunt them down.Cons:1)  As in World of Tanks or War Thunder there will be games you just cannot win due to having a team that does silly things.  Personal performance can only carry you so far and some games are just unwinnable.  2)  Aircraft have no fuel gauge so if you plan to roll up the CV line you better have good micromanagement skills.3)  Some people say the game is insanely grindy.  In the past that has been true however the XP gains have been adjusted to reasonable levels.  This makes it possible for anyone to get into ships earlier than they probably need to be.  It only took 400 games to reach Tier 9 in the CV line but then again most people would say that's too much for an arcade like game.  XP has been doubled since then so hopefully that issue isn't around anymore for newer players.4)  No physics for ships.  You can stack all the ships together and have them occupy the same space.  If anyone shoots they'll hit the others which leads to people never "crossing" eachother to avoid accidentally blowing up the ally who cut across them.  A very cheesy tactic is to move your ship into the same space as the enemy ship so that their team cannot help them without blowing up their ally.  Meanwhile you can just pound away at their ship from within their footprint in the water.  Some ships have no way to lower their guns and cannot hit targets that close... all they can do is hope the smaller ship inside them runs out of ammo as they die a slow painful death.Is this game good?  I think so.  I'd pay $20.00 for this game if they asked since it's on par with the quality you would expect from a $20.00 game.  The matches do not last very long, 15 minutes tops, which means you can knock out a round or two before work or whenver you got a bit of free time and I like that.  Many tactics have evolved as people unlock different ships and soon organized Fleet Battles will come out and give the game a competative aspect.  Give it a shot if you love skill based Free-to-Play games that have no Pay-to-Win.

												Like going to the finest restaurant in town and finding your water is served in styrofoam cups, the flaws in this game do make you roll your eyes, but always over something that doesn't really matter. The core naval combat game seriously rocks. Zaggat rated 5 stars.Battles are 15 minutes long, if you survive that long or decide to stick around and watch the end after you are sunk. Ship on ship combat is nearly perfect, though the boats move a bit too fast for my taste, but you do get used to that. Graphics are nice except for anything written. They use some font that doesn't work well on my PC. Legible when tweaked, but not great.The pay-to-win elements are truly kept in check, unlike most games. To me, this speaks volumes about the devs. They actually understand that a well-balanced game will bring in more money. Every P2W element gives a slight advantage, but this game is so heavily skill-based that those slight advantages can be easily overcome by superior skill.There are 2 main gaming areas: the Battlefield and the Shipyard. The Shipyard is where you get new ships, put equipment on your ship, train your officers, etc. The major flaws in this game have nothing to do with battle. Battle is great. I mean it. Great. The flaws are with peripheral things like: It is hard to register to get the game started, there is no steam overlay (at least for some users currently), when I started the game, I couldn't read anything. Their FAQ page said to make your GUI bigger in Game Options if you can't read the font. The real solution was to turn down my screen resolution one level. Everywhere you look in the Shipyard will be phrases that were obviously translated into English by a computer translator, and then never proofread by a person who actually speaks English. Much of the instructions are tragically non-sensical. Fortunately the wiki is getting bigger everyday, and the forums and guides are good. And players in chat are helpful (which is another nice change of pace). So the Shipyard can be a bit difficult to figure out, but nothing there is real-time. You can always stop and ask for help when confused in the Shipyard. But that's it for flaws. Minor flaws that make you roll your eyes, but nothing that affects the core gaming experience, which is happily rock solid. Lots of newbies think this game is too hard, but it's usually because they don't understand that their small fast low-level ships can get to the enemies' big ships quicker than their own big ships can get there. Then they try to fight the big enemies without the back-up of their own big ships who won't arrive for another minute. This is a thinking-person's game. This game relies on understanding your role in a complex team, which few people seem to get. Then they complain that matches are made that put them up against top tier ships. Well guess what? You have the option to run away! Just at the start of battle, look to see the names of the players in high tier ships and avoid them, noob! It is a fun challenge if you don't play it like a boxing match where if you see an enemy you attack without thinking! There are things for low level players to do besides fight, like capture npc bases to give your team an airfield or something. Sheesh!8.6/10 Would sink while desperately trying to dodge depth charges in my sub again.

												Navy Field 2 is a good game in the sense that you're never bored.  Sure, the grind to the highest tier of ships can be boring at times, but not every game is the same.Let me break the game down really quick and justify why I can recommend this game.  Each game takes 15 minutes to play and every class has a use.  Destroyers can take down Battleships with good torpedo placement and kill subs, Light Cruisers can hunt down Destroyers and aircraft, Heavy Cruisers are very much pocket Battleships and Battleships, well, deals tons of damage from afar but have limited maneuverability and sigh.  Carriers are just as important because you're constantly fighting off enemy aircraft, providing your fleet with line of sight, and bombing other ships.  Sometimes the matchmaking will get a little wonky and put you in games with higher level ships, but I've had games where my lower tier Destroyer will be able to drop a high-tier Battleship so I'm not complaining.  Not too much anyway.The game is not as Pay to Win as most people make it out to be.  It's more of a grindfest more than anything, and the Premium account will make it easier to grind.  It's as simple as that, since there's nothing that's actually limiting gameplay.  Sure, you can spend gold and buy a few Officers and whatnot to edge out on higher-level opponents, but for the most part they are not necessary for the game.So let me go back to the 15 minutes per game part.  Even if you lose because you got blown out of the water, you can quit the game with some reward and begin your next game immediately.  The combat game itself is fantastic for this regard because there's always something to do.  Every second I'm managing my ship's speeds, dodging torpedoes, shooting off torpedoes of my own, training my guns for an effective angle and lead, and being aware of the map at the same time.  Having played RTS and MOBAs competitively, I would say this definitely ranks up there in terms of active things you can do to improve your game.  This is where the skill of the player comes in, and comes in in a big way.  A player that can take full advantage of his ship will be able to come up in a big way vs. a player who doesn't, regardless of tier.Overall, I definitely recommend players give this game a try.  It's fast-paced and can be unforgiving at times, but that's what I look for in a game that's designed around leveling up and tiers.  You need the combat to be highly engaging so the grind doesn't seem endless and that's what Navy Field 2 does very well.  The one thing that the developers needed in the game was proper documentation.  I feel that the game right now is a lot of bro-science.

												Where to start...The game is free-to-play, which also means there's a pay2win aspect somewhere in the game. However, unlike most others, you don't pay to get ships, you need to earn them. The only thing you're paying for (or at least want to pay for), would be the premium 50% boost that helps in the grind through ship tiers later, the officers for an extra boost, and/or extra ship slots to keep more ships (honestly, you don't need more than 5 if you plan on sticking with one or two classes). Otherwise, everything is obtainable through just playing normally.Now, the matchmaking. Yes, it needs some tweaking. You're not always going to be placed against people of your tier level, but I believe there's a good reason behind this, being that you get to experience fighting against different types of ship classes. And remember that the matchmaking puts you against a fleet (not clan fleet, just a fleet) equal to yours, meaning if they have Tier 9, you have buddies who are Tier 9 as well (or Tier 9 equivalent). The downside? You get wrecked if you're not careful.Best advice for new players is to capture islands, sub detect and provide AA, while trying to support your team from behind and survive. Everyone starts out as a Destroyer so you don't get to do much unless you're really good with your torpedoes and shelling first hand (I've sunk Battleships, just saiyan), it's pretty easy. Heck, you might even manage to land a kill steal and get that huge amount of XP. Eventually you'll reach Tier 3 in a few battles if you try to power through all the upgrades and not invest in any of your ship equipment. My friend did it in less than 30 minutes. You CAN face against stronger enemies even at low levels, but that relies on teamwork, not charging into everything.The community. I haven't really talked to many, so I can't really say, but I've had battles won with teamwork where we were outnumbered, some cooperative, some not. It happens.The grind. I'm a fairly new player myself although I've played since February (before dropping it for a while cause gemes), so I have yet to reach that part of the game. I'm still at Tier 5, using Destroyers, and I can tell you the amount of XP and credits you accumulate increase based on the ship tier you're using, so you might get like 300 or 400 at say, Tier 2, before getting 2000 to 3000 at Tier 5. Then again if you think the game's fun and all, it might not be so bad to invest time to grind, but if you're not that kind of person, better decide now whether you want to drop it.Graphics? Ship docks look good. Actual game? Not so much. What, were you expecting some WoW or WT tier graphics?My opinion? The game isn't nearly as close to frustrating me. I just like naval games and try to have fun. :vShould you play it? Well I mean, just because there's a lot of mixed reviews doesn't mean you shouldn't try it out and see for yourself.(NOT SPONSORED BY NAVYFIELD 2)EDIT: So after countless battles, I am now at Tier 7, with ships of different classes also at Tier 7. To be honest, the game isn't really that frustrating once you get used to it, since you win and lose (although you lose more and that's kind of a good thing since XP gain is much faster with losing compared to winning).The grind, however, becomes increasingly harder. And it's more around the amount of XP required for each upgrade before you get to the next ship than the XP gain itself. For me though, it's not a problem, since I enjoy playing the game either way. It gets a bit repetitive here and there, but eventually I managed. With 4 ships at Tier 7 equivalent (under 2 weeks of grinding; 1-3 hours a day), what's to not get bored of? Psst, the maps.

												Question #1: is Navy Field 2 a fun game? Absolutely.Question #2: is Navy Field 2 as good as World of Warships? Not in a million years.That really is the truth of the matter. World of Warships beats NF2 in pretty much every category. It has superior historical accuracy, it's more immersive, it has a larger player base, it has better support, more map and game mode variety, and overall is a better game. NF2 is a top down shooter with arcade models; WoWs is a graphically beautiful simulator with serious ships. There really is no contest. If you have a good enough machine and graphics card to play WoWs, stop reading this and go download it....aw hell, that would be too easy. Okay then: here are four things that NF2 does better.1) NF2 has more ships. A LOT more ships. The US Navy, Royal Navy, IJN and Kreigsmarine are all featured, whereas WoWs is still in open beta and only has the US Navy and IJN. With the occasional exception (no King George V-class battleships), all of the notable ships are there-and yes, that includes the Yamato. And yes, those 18 inch guns hurt like hell.2) NF2 has subs. WoWs does not. While some destroyers in WoWs can be savage little ninjas, you only get true stealth in NF2. It is actually fairly well balanced to boot. It's not easy to use a sub well, but when you do, the rewards are spectacular. Equally, it takes time for destroyer drivers to learn how to hunt a sub. When an experienced sub and an experienced destroyer meet, it leads to a tense game of cat-and-mouse.3) Unlike WoWs, which puts similar tiers against each other, there is no such limitation in NF2. It is entirely possible to play your first game in a massive 15v15 match, with a Yamato and an Iowa blazing away at each other which you whizz about in your pokey little beginner destroyer. You really do have no idea what you'll run into when you hit the Battle button, and the possibilities for emergent game experiences are substantial. While that can lead to some difficult games as you fight against higher-tier ships and more experienced players, it can also be quite fun.4) NF2 has decent community, overall. It is absolutely advisable to join a Fleet; like all multiplayer games, it's best played with friends. Doing damage to a Yamato in your tier 1 destroyer is great; distracting a Yamato while your two friends in their battleships sink the monster is even better.I hope that helps. NF2 is fun-just don't expect it to be as good as WoWs.

												I've only been playing for about a month and I never played NF1, I just added this to steam with the new patch last week. I don't have a deep knowledge of every aspect of NF2, this is more from a new players perspective. Basically, its a fun game that is flawed. The tutorial is short and nearly useless, but after going through that 2-3 times and playing a dozen or so battles and you get the idea. Once you get the hang of leading targets and using the focus fire you start to settle in pretty fast with the different ship types/playstyles.There is a wide variety of ships in branching trees that work logically for the most part. There are a few ships which seem out of sort with dreadnought-era tiered against others from 20-30 years later but these issues end up moot through balancing. Each ship has upgrades for modules which are limited but do add to your ships capability. Each nation you play will have a crew. As you play your crew levels up. This leveling up leads to an annoying amount of micromanaging after battle as you increase crew skills. As the commander levels up you can also add more officers to yield even better crew stats overall. You can pay for gold officers which yield slightly better bonuses than credit officers. There is also an aid you can buy (both silver and gold ones) which can help you gain XP/credits faster. Then there is the economy. The first 3-4 tiers are pretty easy to unlock. After my first two hours or so I had a BB and CA.  Then it starts to slow down and feel a bit grindy by tier 5-6. Ships start costing a lot more but you don't earn much more XP/creds. Rewards for each game sometimes seem totally random. I have gotten near identical rewards for a game where I died early without landing more than a few shots and another with a few kills where I doubled my HP in damage done. Overall, I like NF2. I can't take it too seriously with the P2W elements (consumables, crew/officers, consumable slots etc), but in my opinion its flaws are outweighed by the fun arcade shoot em up style of game play.

This is compensated by the exp needed for the next tier ships not being that much until you try and get a T11 ship. Then the EXP is rediculous for something not much better than a T9 or T10. Subs are an issue too, but any halfway competent DD player can quickly kill submarines. TL;DR Fun game, worth a download since the download is less than a gig of space. Give it a try.

Posted: March 7, 2015
												Long anticipated release answered by great disappointment. You would have thought the game would have come some ways from its 2013 beta release. -Note: play time shows nil, but I've been on it before steam release.-The game revolves around a tedious upward grind on different ship trees, some required to unlock another class (ex. Play as destroyer, unlock heavy cruiser, then unlock carriers). To unlock the next ships, you have to research a string of "upgrades" until next ship is available for research in the end. Quotations around "research" because they seem to have been chosen at random for each ship or are just meaningless (like gun or boiler upgrades that cost you thousands of exp but improves absolutely nothing). Each tier of each class consists of only one ship and even though the first ships come fast, gameplay eventually gets stale and boring. Wasn't a fan of Warthunder but at least they had more variety with several vehicles per tier.Towards the endgame, exp walls take on an exponential climb. If you're a free user, its very unlikely that you'll ever get to touch the endgame ships. And before any SDE fanboy chimes in with "Stop whining, NF1's grind was even worse, this is nothing", then you're missing the point. Anyone can make a game model focusing entirely on a neverending grindfest (with cash/premium shortcuts of course!). It takes very little effort and imagination but it still seems good at raking in the cash from the whales.Ingame:  Depending on ship, controls can be a bit clumsy and matches are always unbalanced to the point of being rigged. Don't be surprised to have your 1895 heavy cruiser facing Battleship Yamato or your submarine 1v2 against a pair of Destroyers on a tiny map. You don't see much teamwork either and ships rarely tend to play on their ship's main roles. And why would they seeing as how the game rewards all the same regardless of what you're doing. Despite the different classes, they all virtually play the same: cap a base, go deal as much damage as you can,  die/kill yourself, then quit back to lobby. Repeat. The faster you get at this, the faster you can progress. Without premium, however, it feels more like you're in a hamster wheel.Surprised this isn't listed as an early release or beta as there's still some bugs. Some aspects like endgame rewards don't even make sense at times. Players that carried team often get rewarded less than the exp farmers who torpedo rush suicide or guys hanging out back taking random potshots. I guess its a work in progress and they'll iron it all out eventually. Right after they release that new set of ship skins in cash shop.It wasn't all bad though. The music is okay I guess. It doesn't get as annoying as NF1's. The ship descriptions were interesting. I haven't tried World of warships yet but from the videos I've seen it looks like a lot more action going on over there. The only people I'd see recommending this with a straight face are diehard armchair admirals who care nothing about gameplay quality or SDE fanboys and suck ups. To everyone else, I'd look elsewhere.

												The particularity of this game is the 3rd person view so you are not stuck in your ship (like World of Warships) but you can see all the map (there is fog of war where you and your allies don’t see). I was searching for a game like that for quite a long time, NF2 is the only one I found. Now, the game:There is no tutorial or sandbox, so get ready to lose your first battles trying to understand how to use your ship. The community may help, using chat or websites giving advices and tips. Otherwise, learn by yourself!Controlling ship is however quite simple, it’s an arcade game. Submarine and Carrier Vessel are harder to control, but have a more interesting value.Graphics are basic too, good point is you can play with a really cheap PC. No damage control (except when low life: you’re slower) so be sure to sink your enemy or he keeps his firepower ;)With one account you may have 6 captains from 4 different countries (US, UK, Germany and Japan, quite balanced) but you won’t be able to up them all unless you spent a huge time on this game.Tech tree isn’t really friendly: some ships are less powerful than the previous rank, and high tier ships require a lot of experience. However, there are nice ships easier to get and enjoyable.Matchmaking is… strange: you may have 10 vs 10 battles (max I saw is 16 vs 16) but you also may get 1 vs 1 or even 1 vs 2… You can play with 2 friends, but you may face other teams, with bigger ships… or far less powerful ones.It’s a free-to-play but I think 2-3 players spent a quite huge amount of money to have such powerful ships… Just avoid those guys and you’ll get interesting battles.The User Interface is a joke: nothing is explained so ask the community or find what you search on internet, chat often goes down, etc.To conclude, how to rate a game both that good and that bad?If you search a naval arcade F2P with intense and quick battles, welcome at NF2!It has a great potential and devs are still working on the game so they will eventually fix major problems (UI, matchmaking) before everyone leaves to find a better game…

Posted: March 16, 2015
												TL;DR:Limited content + grind = boring grind. Player is very limited by things such as barracks space, which can only be expanded by premium currency, but even then at very high costs. P2W items available.===Feels like a shell of a game. A lot of interesting aspects have been dumbed down considerably. Going through the research trees is a dull and grindy process, made worse by the linear upgrades instead of being able to actually change parts of your ships, i.e. the weaponry.Extremely limited barracks space, 5 ship slots, with some heavy price tags on expanding, and even more insane price tags on stat resetting. (2500 gold for a single crew member. I believe you get 625 gold for $4? You've got a bare minimum of 12 crew members. Go figure...) All this makes it impossible for the free player to focus on more than a single type of ship, meaning if your main is a battleship, and you want to have some fun with a carrier or sneak around in a submarine you'll be a lot less effective at it, which partially ruins the fun of it.Also means that you'll pay dearly one way or another for a single mistake during the stat distribution process. Either due to not knowing about all the limitations such as barracks space, because you misjudged the best stat, or change your mind about what path to take... Or even because you did not first heavily research everything in the tech tree and for example now finding out the final ship in your chosen tree is more focused on deck weaponry, not torpedo's. While previous ships were obviously floating torpedo platforms... Just saying...Few maps and even fewer unique situations make the game very repetetive, very quickly. While a grindy feeling is unavoidable in games like these, this only makes it much worse.By definition, the game is P2W. There are boosts available which can give in-game advantage a free player can never get. The free player is limited to the 5% stat increase items, with a relatively large speed decrease, while paying players can get the 10% stat increase items, with a low speed decrease. You can apply a lot of boosts at any single time, making the gap wider. That said, the P2W items should be of minor influence in most situations, but P2W is P2W.They should have paid more attention to World of Tanks's model, as a lot of copied directly out of WoT, but not very well.

Posted: May 10, 2015
												46 hours in, and for the most part the game is fun.  Big differences between this version and NF1:1.  No Gun options, what it comes with is what you get.  Most ships you can upgrade the guns for more damage, better accuracy, and faster reload, but it feels to be a major "miss" when compared to NF1's modifications.2.  No Premium Ships currently.  This is good and bad at the same time, as in NF1's premium ships were by no means a "pay to win" option, but if you got good with them they did help you grind a bit faster.3.  Manual aiming is a huge pain in the A.  Not sure if it's the quicker speed of the game (all ships feel like they are moving at lightspeed in comparison) and manual aiming is too slow.  Combine that with any amount of lagging at all, and you end up with a big loss.  I only ever used auto aim for a few cl's and ca's in NF1, but in this version I haven't managed over 20K damage with manual aim mode.  Maybe it's better with bigger boats, but I'm kinda doubting it.4.  Lag, lock-ups, and another loss.   Any time you "Retreat" or have to Quit the game due to your game lagging out and then freezing, the game counts that battle in your win/loss record as a loss.  Not a big deal if you don't care, but NF1 a lot of us prided ourselves in having a 60-75% Win ratio.  Not possible to maintain that with 5-10 auto losses in a 4 hour sitting due to servers gumming up.  And it's not player's computer, as it seems to be affecting everyone equally, no matter system specs.All in all, the game is fun.  But with the many issues, frustrations, and annoyances, it's just not worth putting any money into the game.  Give it a go maybe if you have some time to kill, but I would give this title a pass.

												This is a game I wanted to like.  I really loved NF1 played it forever and liked it for its uniqueness.Now the genre isn't quiet so empty, here we have NF2, World of Warships is coming out, and presumably more are to come.NF2 to me felt like a dumbed down, simpler, and easier NF1.  Its exactly what I didn't want.  I would have been thrilled at the prospect of a modeled and rebalanced NF1.  Instead we got rid of manual aiming and everything is now auto-aim to some degree which really removed a great amount of player skill from the game.  They just really missed the mark in my opinion, a large part of what made NF1 great even for people not a fan of ships was the interesting and skill oriented aiming system by removing this they effectively removed the main skill from the game.  It feels more like an easy cash farmer now, the sort of f2p program shoved out to make a dime not be a great game.  So its with a great amount of disappointment I'll say I can't recommend this game.

												This game is not a battle of wits or tactics or anything sensible in a naval warfare MMO game, rather the outcome of all battles is down to two things.1. Who has the most health2. Who has better firepowerThere is a recipe for doing well in this game, and those who follow it will win everytime, there is no room for diversity, all your team has to do is launch an enromous volley of torpedoes, and let the battleships camp beyond enemy view range. Vview range as a whole is a pointless idea in maps as small as this, real life warships could make out an enemy ship that was at the edge of the horizon. Any kind of tactics or flanking or whatever will get you not only killed, but swarmed by torpedoe spamming destroyers. In this game numbers win regarless of the ship you sail, or the skill you have. The matchmaking is such bulls**t that you will often run into boats twice your size, and your in a battleship. Personally I don't get the point of the aiming in this game, why can't a normal mouse aim be suffiecent?. Lastly submarines are overpowered to a point where a single one can kill two cruisers, with one torpedoe, and the AA guns are useless, they don't actually shoot at enemy aircraft until they attck you, by then it's too late. Thank god I didn't have to waste money on this game, and the way World of Warships is going, I know what game I'll have on my desktop.

Posted: March 10, 2015
												To start I never played NF1.  I started playing NF2 on steam launch day and had an absolute blast.  Most players were in Destroyers since so many were new, like me, so while variety was lacking it was a level playing field.  By the weekend I was in games that had all ships and let me tell you it sucks trying to figure out your role and how to beat/avoid each enemy ship with so little info about the game and no team work but if you persevere you do learn.  However too many experienced players just rush for quick games bse it is infinitly easier to farm XP and in game currency credits to die quick then try.  Alternately all the new players try to hide behind each other and this is its own problem since the match maker is god aweful at the moment.  I have a level 50 and level 70 captain, highest tier ship is 6 and I am constantly facing tier 8-10 ships which chew up lower tier ships easily.  It is akin to say a level 95 player in World of Warcraft facing off against a level 100.  Assuming equal skill you simply cant beat a ship with 50% more health and damage (Not even including real money items), and thats what youll face most games.  I have even seen countless games they put Tier 2 and 3 ships in to play against Tier 9 and 10 .. seriously ♥♥♥♥♥♥♥♥.  Which leads to the last and most important point.  It is absolutely pay to win and here is why.  All of the ship upgrades you can buy with credits earned in battle are half as effective as real money versions (Accuracy and speed make or break your success and real money buys you more of both).  Real money gets you a temporary premium account giving you a 50% boost to XP and credits which may not sound huge but when you have to do 500-700 battles to afford the next tier ship, well you can do the math.  Premium also unlocks 8 officer slots, though to be fair you can buy 1 day of premium and they stay unlocked.  Real money can also buy 100k Credits which atm is generally what is holding your advancement back.  Lastly real money can make your officers vastly superior giving your ship additional buffs through officer morale items.TLDR and in closing .. until they fix the match making and give a reason for your whole team to actually try to win this game will just be a massive grind of getting owned repeatedly until you either spend or it is nearly Christmas and youve finally lost enough games to get a tier 9 or 10 ship.

												The gameplay in this game feels like it could be good. With a somewhat competent tutorial you probably could've easily understood how to play the game. Too bad your just given a few guides and are slapped on the back.With a somewhat decent ship you probably could do something against others. Too bad your given a rustbucket that will die as soon as it touches water with water pistols instead of cannons. Did I mention that the guns feel like water pistols? They are horribly innacurate and often dont even travel as far as the game says they should. Ever feel like you earned a level up? Well thanks to the fact that your up against fully upgraded, max rank ships you never will! You are just handed level ups, experience, and money just for showing up which does nothing to deter people from just showing up and afking for experience and credits until they can get a max rank ship, and I don't blame them. With the way progression works you can't just get any type of ship you want. You either have to pay a premium or research through a long tree before you may be able to get the lowest tier of a ship that you may not even like playing. The actual gameplay is fairly fun, but you'll be shot out of the water exceedingly quickly if you even dare going into a battle. Have a group of people with you who can survive for awhile and you will just watch or alt tab as you watch... and do nothing else. My most horrendous bone to pick with this game however is the fact that it pretty much punishes new players for being new. You want to play against a veteran? Well even if the veteran stands perfectly still and lets you shoot him with 100% accuracy thanks to the progression system you'll run out of ammo before the guy even gets to half health. You want to play a battleship and an air carrier? Well get ready to pay way too much money or sink hours into the game so you can get ♥♥♥♥♥♥ tier 1 ships of both just to figure out that you hate both ships. want to go to the front line? Well either have really fast movement or really really thick hull or your just going to die, but thanks to the progression system you wont have any ships that are fast enough or tanky enough to do anything. To summarize:Bad TutorialsAggrivating controlsMatches dumb mice against intelligent lionsExceedingly limited ship choicePUNISHES NEW PLAYERS FOR BEING NEW

												I assume at some point in this game's past, some major aspect of the game changed; the number of negative reviews seems unwarrented from my two days (so far) of playing. Sure, the MM is a little strange at times and every so often you get battles that one team is seemingly heavily stacked - but even then it is possible to win. But onto the actual game.It has an arcady feel that, despite the drastically different camera angles and graphics, distinctly reminded me of Battlestations: Midway. Perhaps it's just because of it being an arcade, ship based game, but it doesn't really matter; as I played more I began to enjoy myself more and more. I initially intended to simply play a while whilst another game was in a prolonged maintainence, however this quickly changed into playing it heavily.Initially you start off in an early (often pre-WWI) ship, for the first few tiers you can expect to unlock new ships pretty regularly, I think I'm up to Tier VI as of this review in approximately 10 hours of playing (half way to seven, but I'm probably going to change tree which will slow me). You can chose from 4 nations, with each nation having a relatively balanced tree, whilst still maintaining some national traits (Japanese Torpedos are really, really good for example). Whilst from what I gather the grind starts to become more noticeable from tier V onwards, I've already claimed a couple of tier IX, X and XI ships in my little destroyer and my CA just claimed a high end BB.Which brings me to the MM - yes you get put in battles against high tier ships when you are playing low tier ships. And honestly? If you don't like the concept of merely being a cog in the machine for your team, this might not be the game for you. That said, I loved the challenge of having to take an early destroyer up against teams with Yamatos and Vanguards, and thus I see no issue with the MM. The biggest problem at the moment is slow queue times - but they aren't unbearably bad and at some times of the day you can get matches with decent frequency.The graphics are a little poor - but really, they don't need to be any better, and the visuals are more than adequate for the game. The audio however is good - especially the music which fits the gameplay very well. The UI is a little complicated, and the extremely minimal tutorial you get means you are rather required to ask other players for explanations on certain things; but unlike most of these types of games, the community is helpful.Speaking of the community - not only are they helpful as mentioned above, but also there is far, far less rage than in most online games, all of my matches thus far have been with light hearted people who often laugh at silly mistakes rather than screaming at you. Additionally, in several battles where I've been chasing the last surviving enemy in my DD, high tier BBs have allowed me to score the kill rather than taking it for themselves (which they could easily do) which speaks to a far greater level of decency than I've come to expect from online games.On a final note, the F2P model in this game is instantly recognisable as a fair model - so far as I can tell, there is virtually nothing that is exclusively bought with gold, meaning you are never outclassed by premium vehicles, and never need to buy premium vehicles to sustain yourself, in addition to this the economy seems relatively generous - there are no repair bills, meaning no real drain on your credits other than things you chose to buy.Overall - if you enjoy the challenge and the thought of tactical naval battles, and don't mind the queue times and occasionally unfair matchmaking, this game is definitely worth trying. I had hesitated over downloading it because of reading the negative reviews - my experience of being seal clubbed in other WWII combat games by higher tiers put me off greatly when I read about people fighting tier XI ships with tier II ships, but now that I've tried it, I'm glad that I did as it was certainly worth trying. Seeing as it's free even if you are uncertain - it could be worth downloading and trying it for yourself rather than listening to any review (including my own.)

Developers aparently thought that every cannon and gun avaible for any ship were designed as completly new construction so despite spending a lot of effort to max out your battleship and after that moving to next tier you cant use previously reseached technologies. (ive double checked that guns with same calliber, barrel lenght and markings cant be transfered to other ships within nation). Consumables are some kind of joke even premium ones - i could understand 1 battle only and then re-buy i could understand higher prices for pernament but buying armor of airplanes for 7 days is just riddiculus. Economy - ive said about battle rewards and let say you can handle it and you are thinking well maybe i should check out other nations i have some credits accumulated i wont need to go through every tier. 												I liked this game more then than NF1 except for the upgrades you had in NF1 but they may add them in future updates I think. It reminded me of the ol' days I used to play browsergames like Seafight but than in a WWII style.The game is pretty easy to play if you think logically.There are some high tiers at the beginning that can one shot the starter ship. This should not be a real problem if you understand that when you are small you are also hard to hit. The other way round is this in the favour of the starter. What most beginners forget is that the game is team based so don't sail the ocean on your own or you will be bait for the sharks. I have read a lot of complains about the bad balanced beginning but that is definitely not true. In my first games I already did a lot of damage and sunk some ships already! I would recommend to play the tutorial and read the controls list to learn a bit how the game works. You are not using modern day ships that have missiles instead you have to estimate where to hit the target. This is not difficult and you will learn this fast. I have read complains about planes being impossible to hit. The first time I fired at a plane with AA shells (that you have to use of course) I destroyed it. I noticed that ships without AA shells do auto damage to planes but this is not that effective but good enough to keep them at distance.There are a lot of ships in the game that can be obtained by experience so it takes some effort to get the ship that you want. After de first day I already got a battleship that needs two good shots to destroy a destroyer and is also able to compete against the "bigger ones".You can buy large ships for real money but these ships can also be obtained in free to play. This makes it not a "pay to win" game but more a "pay to win faster" game.Graphics are not that good but in my opinion graphics are not that important in a game. The most important thing is fun and that can be easily get when you blow a fleet with a small destroyer for instance.You must be in the naval subject to play this game otherwise I am afraid that this game is not that fun for you.I am looking forward for World of Warships but I am also looking forward in to future updates of this game because I like naval games like these. I give this game a 9/10 because of the variety of ships and the game-play. -1 for the not that good graphics when you look at NF1 and because the game is not that fun for playing in one session. It is more a game you play until you get bored and log on the next day when you like to blow some battleships again!I played World of Warships and it is.almost the same (not graphically). A bad thing about it is that there are no submarines coming to that game while Navy field has them.And I heard rumours about ships not just from the Navy powers like the USA and Japan but also ships from smaller navies like those from Italy, USSR. and even the Netherlands in the future updates. I don't just recommend playing World of Warships. Play both, World of Warships and Navy field 2!

												Navy Field 2. This game is a serious mix of both strong and very poor development choices. For example, this games ship class system works fairly effectivly, and includes a greater range of ship types than other games. On the other hand, there is almost no form of match making, meaning that bottom and top tier ships end up in the same matches. While the controls are very effective and well thought out, theres no tutorials for features that desperately need them. One consistantly occuring issue I have found is that the game lacks new content. The audio track is very limited, and repeates constantily. There is also a lack of effort to upgrade this game with new features.Summary:Pros:+ Plenty of ship classes, including submarines.+ Large maps.+ Strong controls.+ Large exclusion of premium content prevents new players from buying there way to top tier.Cons:- Lack of new content.- No real match making system.- Repetive sound track.- Inconsistant match search times, ranging from 2 seconds, too 200 seconds.- Largly one upped by world of warships in almost every way.- Desperate need for effective tutorial.Conclusions:This game never really seamed to get of the ground in the first place. Not long after its release, world of warships beta was released and once the finished game was out, navy field 2 was all but finished. So while this game certainly isnt bad, it is also a long ways from being good. The real nail in the coffin is the lack of community. So all in all, this game is definetly starting to see the end of its days.6.5/10
